Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186; ch. 239.proposition: The amount in controversy for the relief sought (actual damages) is within the monetary limits of the Boston Municipal Court, Roxbury Division, and venue and jurisdiction are proper in this Court because the Premises are located in Roxbury, Suffolk County (see, e.g., Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186; ch. 239).

Javins v. First Nat\u2019l Realty Corp.,.raw_text: Javins v. First Nat’l Realty Corp., 428 F.2d 1071 (D.C. Cir. 1970)
Javins v. First Nat\u2019l Realty Corp.,.proposition: Under Massachusetts common law, every landlord’s lease includes an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment under which the tenant is entitled to the use and enjoyment of the leased premises without substantial interference by the landlord.

State Sanitary Code (105 CMR 410.000 et.raw_text: State Sanitary Code (105 CMR 410.000 et seq.)
State Sanitary Code (105 CMR 410.000 et.proposition: See also state and local habitability standards such as the State Sanitary Code (105 CMR 410.000 et seq.) and public-health statutes empowering local boards of health to inspect and order repairs (Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 111 §127).

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 111 \u00a7127.proposition: See also state and local habitability standards such as the State Sanitary Code (105 CMR 410.000 et seq.) and public-health statutes empowering local boards of health to inspect and order repairs (Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 111 §127).

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186 (landlord-tenant.raw_text: Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186 (landlord-tenant law generally)
Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186 (landlord-tenant.proposition: Massachusetts law and the State Sanitary Code set minimum standards of fitness for human habitation; a landlord's knowing failure to remedy hazardous or habitability conditions, or permitting conditions that substantially interfere with a tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises, may constitute breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and may support an award of damages.

105 CMR 410.000 (State Sanitary Code: Mi.raw_text: 105 CMR 410.000 (State Sanitary Code: Minimum Standards of Fitness for Human Habitation)
105 CMR 410.000 (State Sanitary Code: Mi.proposition: Massachusetts law and the State Sanitary Code set minimum standards of fitness for human habitation; a landlord's knowing failure to remedy hazardous or habitability conditions, or permitting conditions that substantially interfere with a tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises, may constitute breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and may support an award of damages.

Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.proposition: Massachusetts courts and courts in other jurisdictions have repeatedly recognized that landlord failure to repair significant defects, or conduct interfering with the tenant's peaceful possession, may constitute breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment or the implied warranty of habitability and that tenants may recover actual damages.
Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.support_reasoning: The case squarely recognizes an implied warranty of habitability in residential leases and holds that significant defects in essential facilities—such as plumbing, sewage, heat, and safety—constitute a breach of that warranty. It further holds that tenants may recover contract damages, including reimbursement of all rent paid and additional compensatory damages for discomfort and annoyance, even while remaining in possession. Although framed in terms of habitability rather than a covenant of quiet enjoyment, it directly supports the proposition that landlord failure to repair serious defects can give rise to actual damages.
Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.relevant_excerpt: “[W]e now hold expressly that in the rental of any residential dwelling unit an implied warranty exists in the lease… that the landlord will deliver over and maintain, throughout the period of the tenancy, premises that are safe, clean and fit for human habitation…. Because we hold that the lease of a residential dwelling creates a contractual relationship… the standard contract remedies of rescission, reformation and damages are available… The tenant will be liable only for ‘the reasonable rental value [if any] of the property in its imperfect condition during his period of occupancy.’ … [D]amages should be allowed for a tenant’s discomfort and annoyance arising from the landlord’s breach of the implied warranty of habitability.”

Sommer v. Kridel, 74 N.J. 446, 378 A.2d.proposition: Massachusetts courts and courts in other jurisdictions have repeatedly recognized that landlord failure to repair significant defects, or conduct interfering with the tenant's peaceful possession, may constitute breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment or the implied warranty of habitability and that tenants may recover actual damages.
Sommer v. Kridel, 74 N.J. 446, 378 A.2d.support_reasoning: The opinion in Sommer v. Kridel concerns a landlord’s duty to mitigate damages when a residential tenant abandons the premises. It does not address landlord failures to repair, interference with quiet possession, the covenant of quiet enjoyment, or the implied warranty of habitability, nor does it discuss tenant recovery of actual damages for such breaches. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for the proposition regarding breach of quiet enjoyment or habitability based on failure to repair or interference with possession.
Sommer v. Kridel, 74 N.J. 446, 378 A.2d.relevant_excerpt: This Court has taken the lead in requiring that landlords provide housing services to tenants in accordance with implied duties which are hardly consistent with the property notions expressed in Muller v. Beck, supra, and Heckel v. Griese, supra. See Braitman v. Overlook Terrace Corp., 68 N.J. 368 (1975) (liability for failure to repair defective apartment door lock); Berzito v. Gambino, 63 N.J. 460 (1973) (construing implied warranty of habitability and covenant to pay rent as mutually dependent); Marini v. Ireland, 56 N.J. 130 (1970) (implied covenant to repair); Reste Realty Corp. v. Cooper, 53 N.J. 444 (1969) (implied warranty of fitness of premises for leased purpose).

Gen. Laws ch. 186; ch. 239).

105 CMR 410.000 et seq..proposition: See also state and local habitability standards such as the State Sanitary Code (105 CMR 410.000 et seq.) and public-health statutes empowering local boards of health to inspect and order repairs (Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 111 §127).

Sommer v. Kridel, 74 N.J. 446, 378 A.2d.proposition: Massachusetts courts and courts in other jurisdictions have repeatedly recognized that landlord failure to repair significant defects, or conduct interfering with the tenant's peaceful possession, may constitute breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment or the implied warranty of habitability and that tenants may recover actual damages.
Sommer v. Kridel, 74 N.J. 446, 378 A.2d.support_reasoning: The case concerns whether a residential landlord has a duty to mitigate damages after a tenant abandons the premises. It does not address landlord failure to repair, interference with quiet enjoyment, the implied warranty of habitability, or tenant recovery of actual damages for those types of breaches. The court briefly cites earlier New Jersey habitability/repair cases only to support treating leases as contracts, not to discuss quiet enjoyment or repair-based claims themselves.
Sommer v. Kridel, 74 N.J. 446, 378 A.2d.relevant_excerpt: This Court has taken the lead in requiring that landlords provide housing services to tenants in accordance with implied duties which are hardly consistent with the property notions expressed in Muller v. Beck, supra, and Heckel v. Griese, supra. See Braitman v. Overlook Terrace Corp., 68 N.J. 368 (1975) (liability for failure to repair defective apartment door lock); Berzito v. Gambino, 63 N.J. 460 (1973) (construing implied warranty of habitability and covenant to pay rent as mutually dependent); Marini v. Ireland, 56 N.J. 130 (1970) (implied covenant to repair)…
